title: Davidson Andeh
text:
Davidson Andeh (born January 17, 1958) is a retired <a href="boxing">boxer</a> from <a href="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, who won the world title in the <a href="lightweight">lightweight</a> division (– 60 kg) at the second <a href="1978%20World%20Amateur%20Boxing%20Championships">World Amateur Championships</a>, held in <a href="Belgrade">Belgrade</a>, <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>. In the final he defeated <a href="Vladimir%20Sorokin%20%28boxer%29">Vladimir Sorokin</a> from the <a href="USSR">USSR</a>.
Andeh represented his native country at the <a href="1976%20Summer%20Olympics">1976 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Montreal%2C%20Quebec">Montreal, Quebec</a>, Canada, but Nigeria withdrew from the competition due to the participation of <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>, and so the win in the first round of the <a href="featherweight">featherweight</a> division (– 57 kg) was given to <a href="India">India</a>'s <a href="Rai%20Sik">Rai Sik</a>.
Andeh became professional in 1980, and captured the <a href="African%20Boxing%20Union">African</a> lightweight title in 1983 by defeating <a href="Tapsoga%20Tiga">Tapsoga Tiga</a> of <a href="Togo">Togo</a>. He retired from competition in 1987, with a record of 18 wins (12 knockouts), five losses and one no-contest.
